content:
Detonation from spark struck for fire hurls ships out to
sea.

Tightening belt to counteract hunger: when loosened person
falls dead.

Blood of brother and sister (and smoke from their funeral
pyres) refuses to mingle.

Two children of different sex, not related, have such close
resemblance that even parents cannot tell them apart.

Woman who has been widowed twenty-two times marries a man who has been a
widower twenty times. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

To
fourth story (or the like). Type 530; Cosquin Contes indiens 333ff.; Irish
myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Philippine
(Tinguian): Cole 103; Marquesas: Handy 114; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/499).
child:
Crossing a river with help of a fig tree whose branches
touch the opposite bank.
Jumping over a ditch which is really an ocean.
Man clears river of enormous width in one leap.
Miraculous spring bursts forth for holy person.
Spring bursts forth where saint spills water from his bell.
Magic spring flows from roots of tree at command of Jesus.
Well rises so holy person does not have to draw from it.
Well rises so maiden can draw without exerting herself.
Well rises for pious man’s sheep.
Dry spring restored by removal of certain stone.
At certain time sheep thrown into well become crimson.

Severed head of impious man in well causes water to become
bitter during part of each day.
Irish myth: *Cross; French Canadian: Sister Marie Ursule.
Spring miraculously breaks forth against wrongdoer.
Well floods when gazed upon until mass is said over it.
Bones of bird constantly thrown up from well.

Fb ”å“ III 1187a; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 209 n. 8; Africa
(Kaffir): Theal 63.
River arches over saint’s body like a vault.

(Cf. †F931.9.1, †V220.)
*Ward Catalogue II 640 No. 17; Crane Miraculis 104 No. 40.

Stream becomes hot in which saint performs his ascetic
devotions.
Well of oil runs into river.
River dries up for a day.
River dries up its waters out of sympathy.

In dead of night waters of stream cease flowing and stand
perfectly still.
River boils when ashes of hearts are cast into it.

River rises to prevent body’s being carried over it against
dying man‘s wish.
River rises to prevent advance of army.
River rises to prevent meeting of hostile armies.
River rises to prevent escape of thieves.
Treacherous river overflows and drowns victims.
Shallow river rushes up to drown man.
River piles up to a height of three hundred miles.
Ford across impassable river created by saint.
River divides into two parts after rape in its bed.

Firelike waters of river used by strange beings to cook
flesh.
S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 171.

Punishment for woman’s having washed a child with a fish. Finnish: Aarne FFC
XXXIII 47 No. 90; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 135 No. 90.
Sea does not encroach on burial place of saint.
Sea behaves like solid earth when man is buried in it.
Waves reverberate at preparation for battle.
Waters of sea arch over people like a vault.
Sea yields people whatever they desire.

Paths open up in sea for each tribe (one for each of
Israel‘s tribes).
Sea piles up to height of sixteen hundred miles.
Book dropped in water by saint not wet.
Dashing sea does not touch saint’s cowl.
Robe sent to saint on stream not wet.

Water sinks to bottom, mud rises to surface to keep prophet
from drowning.

Waters transformed to blood for Egyptians but not for
Hebrews.
Water stops flowing when no longer needed.
Chewed nut spread on waters clarifies them.

content: Extraordinary occurrences connected with pond (pool, tank).
child: Huge tank has no water in spite of plentiful rains.
Ice forms while fish leaps from pool.
Gravel rises from bottom as hero enters lake.

When dead man‘s body is thrown into lake, water turns pitch
black and all living creatures therein die.
Books show sorrow for owner‘s death by falling from shelf.
Chariots, stones, weapons join in keen at hero’s death.

content: Sword pierces rock when possessor will break it.
child: Sword is spoken to as to human being.

content: Waters react to words of poet.

child:
Stream of blood flows from it into silver cup. (Cf. †D1086.)
*Brown PMLA XXV (1910) 1; *Gaster FL II 57; Irish myth: *Cross; Welsh:
MacCulloch Celtic 202.

Man
cuts into dry bone that bleeds. Fb ”høle“ I 747a; Japanese: Ikeda.
Dry bone smells as sign of forgiveness.

content: Vessel of poisoned ale inverted; only poison flows out.

child: Stark Der Alraun; Taylor JAFL XXXI 561.

content: Dice game that lasts for nine years.

child:
Princess stands in middle of dried-up tank so serpent will
release the water, which he had swallowed up completely.

Buffalo sucks hero with water it is drinking and throws him
up again in game of hide-and-seek.

Tigress swallows abandoned baby again and again, but it
comes out from behind.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at birth of holy person
(hero).
Extraordinary nature phenomena at birth of royalty.
Thunder report at birth of king.

Shower of gold and silver rains upon king‘s ship at birth
of his children.
Storm signs betray newly born child’s chiefly rank.
Extraordinary nature phenomena at birth of hero.
Extraordinary precipitation at birth of hero.

(Cf. †F962.) Irish myth:
*Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys.
Shower of lotuses at birth of hero.
Exhibition of lights at saint‘s birth.
Bells ring without human hands when a saint is born.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at rebirth: nine worlds
tremble.
When girl (princess) is born, earth is filled with light.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at death of holy person
(hero).
Nature fruitless after death of hero.

Rainbow stretches from monastery to heaven at saint’s
death.
Rock bursts into flames at hero‘s death.
Great light appears on night of holy man’s death.
Earthquake at death of important person.
Earthquake when good man is murdered.
Winter‘s day changes to summer’s day at saint‘s funeral.
Sun shines but two hours the day of hero’s funeral.
Extraordinary nature phenomena during furious battle.
Nature‘s lament at the Temple’s destruction.
Extraordinary nature phenomena at anger of saint.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at prisoner‘s miraculous
release.
Extraordinary nature phenomena on night of fratricide.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at cruel treatment of innocent
person.

Extraordinary nature phenomena at moving of saint’s
remains.

Earthquake announces victorious return of hero after long
absence.

Extraordinary natural phenomena at giving of Tora at Mount
Sinai.
Man puts his horse in his sleeve when he does not need it.

content: Irish: O’Suilleabhain 107, Beal XXI 334; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
Man brings objects received during dream. Krappe Balor 122ff.; Icelandic:
*Boberg.

Still there when person wakes. *Kittredge Witchcraft 222f., 534 nn. 90--97;
Alphabet No. 299; Icelandic: Boberg; England: Baughman.
Man is maltreated in dream so that he feels it next day.
Fight in dream with real result.

content: One animal jumps through body of another.
child: Monkey jumps through body of tiger.
Whelp leaps through body of hound.

Gifts are obtained or fall from heaven: flowers (roses),
crown of gold, blossoms or thorns, bells, gems, books, sword, etc.
Electric storm breaks island into three parts.

*Saintyves Essais de folklore biblique 1ff.; Irish: Plummer cxxxvii, cxxxviii,
*Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: Moreno Esdras, *Neuman.
Pillar of fire reaches from heaven to earth.
Fire from heaven cannot be quenched by water.
Fire from heaven burns and freezes.
Star drops from heaven: is money.

Irish
myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Marquesas: Handy
65.
Shower of blood for three days and three nights.
Dew of blood from fingers of repentant woman.
Hailstones, each as large as a crabapple.
Icicles gathered by saint as firewood burn.
Mist settles over lake after fight with serpent.
Crozier falls from heaven for saint.
Marvelous picture falls from sky in storm.
Mysterious leaf falls on church altar.
Raindrops as large as man‘s hand.
Flame indicates presence of beautiful woman.

(Cf. †F1041.8.1. and
cross references.) Malay, Indonesian: Dixon 222 n. 26.
Color of flame indicates what is burning.

Blue for furniture, white for money, red for person.
Indonesian: Dixon 226.

Burning pit will close only if armed rider will plunge into
it.
Flame indicates place where innocent person was murdered.

content:
Hero
in departing takes his house with him. N. A. Indian: Kroeber JAFL XXI 224.

child: Wind serves Solomon as horse and carries him everywhere.

Extraordinary wind blows arrows shot against Christians
back against enemy.

Extraordinary wind bursts open locked doors of church to
show that dead pope is worthy of burial there.
Wind carries ogre to his castle.

content: Man fishes up two blind women from a well.

child:
Fb ”solstråle“; De Vries Germanischromanische Monatsschrift 1922, 40 n.
2; *Loomis White Magic 29; Irish: Plummer cxxxix, *Cross, O’Suilleabhain 101,
106, Beal XXI 332f.; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 301 No. 19, 306 No. 19, 309
No. 10, 328 No. 6; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 146 No. 1805A, 1805B.
Gospel-book hung from saint‘s shoulders without strap.

Elephant allows jackal to quench his thirst by entering
through his mouth to his stomach.
Person unwittingly swallows snake, which kills him.

content:
Irish myth: *Cross; Jewish: Neuman; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth
132, 437; Tuamotu: ibid 503; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 322 n. 159b.
child:
S. A. Indian
(Cashinawa): Métraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 686.

content: Tent-house folded and swallowed as means of carrying it.
Hero‘s marvelous sword falls and cuts off hand of enemy.
Saint preaches for three days and three nights.
Eye bursts forth from overstrain of voice.

child: Inlay melts from sword with heat of striking.
Weapons confined by flying nets of hair in furious battle.
No rest or food. Irish myth: *Cross.
Marks of furious battle left in rock.
Deep streams of blood flow during battle.
Warriors use teeth after they exhaust weapons.
Soldiers fight so closely river is forced from bed.
Man and his camels rise into air.
Person has red and black countenance after being burned.

content: Tub of water dropped neither breaks nor spills.

child:
De Vries FFC LXXIII 388; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL
XXIX 12.
Great flock of birds lift grayhound and garments into air.
Hawk carries hand of man to saint displeased by handclasp.
Bird brings flower from foreign land.
Toad carries seven stone mortars on his head.
Crab carries in his ear cat, tiger, bamboos, river.
Snail grows and fills house entirely.

N. A. Indian (Tahltan): Teit JAFL XXXIV 229 No. 36,
(Tlingit): Swanton BBAE XXXIX 151.

*Type 621; BP III 483; *Köhler-Bolte I 134, *601a; *Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. XVI 242 No. 23, XVII 229; Polívka Archiv. f. slav. Philol. VII 317 No.
65, XXVI 464; Sébillot France III 334 n. 4; Leskien Balkanmärchen No. 20;
*Cosquin Contes indiens 529ff.; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 5; Algerian:
Desparmet Contes Pop. rec. à Blida 407; India: Thompson-Balys.
Cat grows as large as a cow in a minute.
Bull melts away after evil spirit has issued from him.
Animals killed by trickster‘s breaking wind.
Fiery bolt from heaven kills devastating animal.
Ashes thrown into stream dissolve animals.

King of cats killed by glowing mass of iron thrown by
saint.
Giant magic boar slain by tearing out entrails from behind.
Salmon caught out of season for saint.
Salmon comes every seventh year to certain place.
Stranded fish do not decay for a year.
Bird controls sex and appearance of offspring.

Hatches seven eggs--three under each wing and one under
breast. The right wing hatches three red males, the left three green females.
The egg under the breast shares the characteristics of both sex and color--but
dies. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

As protection against a greater horse, hero‘s horse is sewed in nine
buffalo-hides. Köhler-Bolte I 469; *Cosquin Contes indiens 417ff.
Hero unharmed by serpent which coils around his waist.

Icelandic: Snorra Edda Gylf. XLI, Boberg; Danish: Schmidt
DF XXXIX 44ff.; Maori: Clark 29.

Clerics and property cast safely on shore when enemies
attempt their drowning.
Fisherman dragged through sea by seal escapes.
Animal escapes by slipping out of skin.

content:
Hero goes into tree to spend the night. *Type 327A, 613; Icelandic: *Boberg;
German: Grimm No. 163; India: Thompson-Balys.
Arrow shot to heaven returns bloody.

Hdwb. d. Märch. I 102a;
Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Knife plunged into earth comes out bloody.

(Cf. †F912.3.) Bird
eaten by king pecks on his stomach. King vomits and bird escapes. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 37 No. 244; Japanese: Ikeda.

Every morning girl’s shoes are danced to pieces. *Type 306; BP III 78; *Fb
”sko“ III 288b; Finnish: Aarne FFC XXXIII 39 No. 8**.
Woman has worn out carriage-load of shoes with walking.
Wearing shoes only when crossing river.
Bill of sale written on man‘s sandal.

God swallows his wife and incorporates her into his own
being.

*Types 123, 333, 700; Fb ”kat“ II 108b; Saintyves Perrault
227ff.; Persian: Carnoy 302; Hindu: Penzer IX 49.
Winged serpent as boat: passengers within.
Animal with men in its belly playing cards, etc.
Frog eats a rat, a baker, a man, and a horse.

Fish (or water monster) swallows a man. *Frazer Old Testament III
82; *H. Schmidt Jona 127f.; *Wesselski Märchen 213 No. 18; Clouston Tales I
403ff.--Irish myth: *Cross; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 11; Italian:
Basile Pentamerone V No. 8, Rotunda; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas@2 IV 27,
275, *Neuman; Babylonian: Spence 87; India: *Thompson-Balys, *Penzer II 193, VI
154 n. 3, Keith 173; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 261; Oceanic (Cook Group,
Melanesia, Indonesia): Dixon 69, De Vries‘s
list No. 211; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 443; Marquesas: Handy 137; S. A. Indian
(Bakairi): Alexander Lat. Am. 313.
Party in canoe swallowed by great clam.

Am. Indian (Ladino, Honduras and Nicaragua): Conzemius
BBAE CVI 169.
Man builds boat and sails about in giant‘s belly.

Has whole towns of people and buildings, etc. inside. Italian: Basile
Pentamerone V No. 8 (fish); Africa: Werner African 198, (Zulu): Callaway 55, 78ff.,
85ff., 192, 325, 332, (Kaffir): Theal 84, 139f., 176, (Mpongwe): Nassau 34, 46
Nos. 4, 6, (Basuto): Jacottet 70 No. 11, 76 No. 12, 122 No. 17, 214 No. 31,
(Ibo Nigeria): Thomas 115, 203 No. 1.
Toad (as man) swallows all women’s earthenware.

S. A. Indian
(Cashinawa): Métraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 685.

S. A. Indian (Cashinawa): Métraux BBAE
CXLIII (3) 686.

content:
(Cf. †X1723.1.) *Types
123, 333, 450, 700; *BP I 37, 40, 389; *Penzer VI 154 n. 3; Wesselski Märchen
213 No. 18; Saintyves Perrault 227ff.--Irish myth: *Cross; Jewish: bin Gorion
Born Judas@2 I 165, 372; Persian: Carnoy 302; Hindu: Keith 173; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Oceanic (Cook Group, Melanesia, Indonesia, Australia): Dixon
69, 296; Eskimo (Smith Sound): Kroeber JAFL XII 175; N. A. Indian: *Thompson
Tales 321 n. 159a; S. A. Indian (Bakairi): Alexander Lat. Am. 313, (Cashinawa):
Métraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 686; Africa: Werner
African 221, (Zulu): Callaway 55, 78ff., 85ff., 325, 332, (Kaffir): Theal 84,
142, 176, (Basuto): Jacottet 72, 76, 214 Nos. 11, 12, 31; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS
XVII 270 No. 82.
child: Smith swallowed by water-monster and rescued by saint.

Deity lights a great fire, and all the children ogress has
devoured come out of it.
Victim kills swallower from within by burning.

*Wesselski Märchen 213
No. 18; Hartland Perseus III 15; Finnish: Kalevala rune 17; Oceanic (Cook
Group, Melanesia, Indonesia): Dixon 69; Africa (Zulu): Callaway 332ff.
Victim kills swallower from within by cutting.

Irish myth: *Cross; Mono-Alu: Wheeler 55; New Hebrides:
Codrington 365; Cook Islands: Beckwith Myth 503; Marquesas: ibid 502; S. A.
Indian (Eastern Brazil): Lowie BBAE CXLIII (1) 434; Africa (Cameroon): Meinhof
60, (Kaffir): Theal 84, 176, (Basuto): Jacottet 122.

Swallowed person eats on swallower‘s liver (heart) until
disgorged.
Swallowed person tickles serpent’s throat and is disgorged.
Miracles on first night of Passover.
All miracles created by God at creation.

Miracles in the desert come to an end with death of Miriam,
Aaron and Moses.

Extraordinary threefold death: falling from rock and tree,
drowning.
Extraordinary threefold death: wounding, burning, drowning.

content: Inanimate object acts as if living.
child: Doorpost of room rises for holy person.
Gate swallows axes trying to force it open.
Altar shakes when unworthy man is elected.
Twelve stones unite to become one.

Mountain moves so that its rocks enter into caves of other
mountain.

Cake, planted in the field, grows and after a time bears
cakes.

content:
Substituted silver hand used as if it were of flesh and
blood.
Extraordinary heads act as living objects.

child: Hoofs of horses drop from their feet because of heat.
Apertures of animals‘ bodies closed up in certain land.

Breton: Sébillot
Incidents s.v. ”cheval“. Cf. Type 530.

Looks so intently at it that it heats and cooks. N. A.
Indian (Maidu): Dixon BAM XVII 65.
Bird calls out the hours. Hdwb. d. Märchens s.v. ”Baum bewacht“.
Man rides on back of fleeing wild boar.
Sheep never harmed by wild beasts.
One bull, one cow survive plague.
Swine kick trees to cause fruit to fall.
Milk from saint’s cows forms lake.

Animals distribute parts of man‘s body in accordance with
prophecy.
Animal dives into lake and disappears.
Swarms of quails serve as food for Israelites.
Swarms of birds darken sun and moon.
Frog pierces hardest metals and marbles.
Frogs cast themselves into oven-flames and devour bread.
Garden becomes wilderness because of owner’s wickedness.

After persecuted queen has been driven away from palace,
trees do not bear fruits, flowers cease to bloom, and birds do not sing.

content: Grass refuses to grow in certain spot.

Extraordinary event has happened there. Fb ”græs“ I 499b, IV 188a; Taylor Attila and Modern Riddles, JAFL
LVI (1943) 136--37; Icelandic: Boberg.
child:
Grass will not grow where blood of murdered person has been
shed.
Walking on grass-blades without bending them.
Irish myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 189.

content: Miraculous blossoming and bearing of fruit.
child:
*Type 756 ABC, 757; BP III 463, 465, 471 n. 1; *Dh II 265ff.; Fb ”nåde“ II 726b, ”stav“ III 541b; RTP IX 504, XIII 505, XV 61, XIX 66, 336, 532, XXI 123,
XXV 141; **Andrejev FFC LIV 34, LXIX 126, 129ff., 241ff.; Saintyves Essais de
folklore biblique 61ff.; Zs. f. Vksk. X 196f., XIII 72, XV 393; Alphabet No.
568; *Loomis White Magic 94, 114; Goebel Jüdische Motive im märchenhafte
Erzählungsgut (Gleiwitz, 1932) 34ff.; Irish: Plummer cliv, *Cross, O’Suilleabhain 108, Beal XXI 318, 334; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.
No. 186; Jewish: *Neuman; West Indies: Flowers 438.
Dry rod blossoms on night of saint’s birth.

Type 755; Fb ”sten“ III 554a, ”rose“ III 80a; P. Saintyves Le
Thème du bâton qui reverdit (Revue d‘Histoire et de
Littérature religieuses, III [1912] 330--49, 421--54).
Thorn growing in wound becomes tree.

Done at saint’s request. *Dh II 9; Alphabet No. 290;
Irish: Plummer cliv, *Cross.

)
tree bears apples (”fair fruit“). Irish myth: *Cross.

Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 686; Alphabet No. 475; *Pease Cicero De Divinatione 217
(U. of Illinois Studies in Language and Literature); Stier in Pauly-Wissowa XV
(1932) 2026; Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo II 102, MacCulloch Eddic 320; Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Fruit produced out of season at saint‘s request.

Tree bears apples only at Christmas. Blossoms at midnight and is full of apples
by morning. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 559.
Tree blossoms at midnight on Twelfth Night.
Flowers spring up when saint strikes ground.
Trees put forth leaves on arrival of God in paradise.
Creeper which blossoms once only in a thousand years.

content: Extraordinary behavior of trees and plants--miscellaneous.
child: Sour fruits made sweet by saint.

*Loomis White Magic 80; Irish: Plummer cliv, *Cross;
Japanese: Ikeda.
Leaves of tree open and close to give saint passage.
Leaves of tree make melody for saints.
Tree seizes person and lifts him up.

Africa (Nago): Trautmann
La Littérature populaire à la Côte des Esclaves (Paris, 1927) 6ff.
Tree grows through handle of saint‘s bell.

Hollow in tree grows over, giving sanctuary to relics
within.

Flower from otherworld (Land of Promise) miraculously
appears to persons (saints).

Trees spring up to commemorate birth of primitive hero
(demigod, deity).
Trees spring up from blood spilled on ground.
Tree sheds all its leaves out of sympathy.

Magic tree will allow person to take only two of its
fruits.
Extraordinary tree supports pious man and his family.
Tree‘s branches turn upward when idolators rest beneath it.
Tree which has two singing blossoms.
Tree acts as master of ceremonies while gods drink.
Trees wither when tragic things happen.

content:
*Type 755; H. C. Andersen ”Skyggen“; Fb ”skygge“ III 347; *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachträge
133ff.; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 47 No. 325A*.
child:
Man attends devil‘s school to learn witchcraft, has no
shadow afterward.

Man has witch aid him in reaping contest, the devil to get
the hindmost.

The devil tries to take the man but gets shadow instead. (Cf.
†G303.19, †K210.) Scotland: Baughman.
Person wanders unceasingly for hundred and fifty years.

content: Person lives without food or drink for a year (or more).
Type 706; Irish myth: *Cross; German: Grimm No. 31.
child: Person lives on water (from holy well) for a year.

content:
Ship wrapped with feather-beds and canvass and pitched (so
as to save it).
Hand from heaven writes on wall.

child:
*Type 800; *BP I 342;
*Hdwb. d. Märch. s.v. ”Schneider im Himmel“.
Magician carries mistress with him in his body.

She in turn has paramour
in hers. Wesselski Märchen 186 No. 1; *Cosquin Études 276ff.; Chinese:
Chavannes 500 Contes I 378 No. 109.

Ascetic carries woman in his hair, but she has two lovers
in her cloak and outwits him.
Man hides sister in wound in his thigh to protect her.
Garment hidden in hole cut in thigh.
Jewell hidden in wound cut in thigh.
Other parts of person‘s body as hiding place.
Key to house concealed in man’s heart.

content: Disintegration: man eats himself up or dismembers himself.

child:
(Cf. †H1023.6.) Types 425, 428, 756C*;
Andrejev FFC LIV passim; Boberg Classica et Medievalia I 1938.

content:
India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Korean: Zong
in-Sob 161.
child: Bean, straw, and coal go journeying.

Coal burns straw in two and falls into the water. Bean
laughs until it splits. *Type 295; BP I 135; India: Thompson-Balys.

Turtle recruits war-party of strange objects (knife, brush, awl, etc.) and
animals. Because of their nature the companions get into trouble. N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 302 n. 108. Cf. Japanese: Mitford 185ff., Ikeda.
Eggplant, needle, and cowdung go on warpath.

Darkness comes in daytime in order to save life of maiden
about to be executed.
Premature darkness at time of execution of innocent people.
Sun darkened at death of holy person.

Usener Kleine Schriften IV 307; Jewish: Neuman; Icelandic:
*Boberg.
Sun does not rise at death of hero.
Extraordinary darkness not dispelled by artificial means.

content: Voices from heaven (or from the air).

child: Thin cloud in form of rainbow.

content:
Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 91, 92;
Jewish: *Neuman.
child:
*Type 575; *BP II 131;
Penzer IX 149; Köhler-Bolte I 120; *Chauvin V 231 No. 130; Greek: Frazer
Apollodorus II 139 n. 2 (Daedalus); India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Ferguson
35.
Flight so high that sun melts glue of artificial wings.

Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 139 n. 2
(Icarus).
Flight so high that eyelids drop from cold.

Man kicked so hard that he flies through the air and is
never seen again.
Several suns or moons appearing in sky simultaneously.
Eclipse of sun and moon in God‘s proximity.

Sun, moon, and stars do not shine seven days, mourning
Adam’s death.
God‘s praise chanted by the heavenly bodies.
Heavenly bodies bear witness for and against man.
Sun refuses to shine when murder is done.
Sun travels from west to east.

Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 164 n. 1; Jewish: Gaster
Exempla 185 No. 2b, 201 No. 78, *Neuman.
Sun returns to sunrise to help sick man.
Sun warns man of approaching assassin.

Sun shines for twelve days and nights after death of holy
person.
Sun does not shine on island of druidry.

Sun turned from one hour to another through the prayer of
saint (Moses).
Eclipse of sun at important historical events.
Sun sets early to hide fugitive.
Bright star indicates birth of holy person.

*Toldo I 327; Matthew 2: 2; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Babylonian: Spence 53.
Star moves from west to east.
Stars drop on grave during conjuration.
Many moons at the same time.
Moon warns sleeping man of approaching assassin.

content: Creation of a person by cooperation of skillful men.

child: Descent into ocean in glass box.

Jewish: Gaster Exempla 186 No. 5; bin Gorion Born Judas@2
III 136, 306, *Neuman.

content:
Man suddenly acquires long gray beard on scaffold at
execution.

child: Marvelous light reveals man hiding from saint.

Hero‘s light: appears around head of hero aroused to
extraordinary feats of valor.
Rumble in earth attends slaying of giant serpent.

Fight with monster child causes earth to rock like waves of
the sea.

Sandhill grows around lover keeping watch till it covers
all but his head.

content: Milk has taste of wine and honey.
Arm grows longer from giving alms.
Person lives on after being cut through by sword.
child: Person lives on after having heart cut free.
Heart moves about within his chest. Irish myth: Cross.
Person lives on with intestines exposed.

content:
Armies miraculously separated (kept from coming to battle,
etc.
child: Angel forbids armies to approach each other.

content: Food does not spoil saint’s clothing.

child: Senses regained when person speaks his name.

Cross-eyes straighted when hero sets head of slain opponent
upon his own.
Deformity cured by waves of sea.
Gaping wound closed with slab of wood.
Wounds healed by bath of marrow.
Saint‘s palm over wound causes spearhead to come forth.
Fat of crow as remedy for king’s wounds.
Paunch opened and fat taken out to cure stomach.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 679.

Enemy cured by poisoned cake he has sent to holy man in
order to destroy him.
Immunity to poison by eating poisons.

content:
Usually by saint. Toldo II 96; India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera I 633; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 87, 260f.; Africa (Upoto):
Einstein 127.
child: Barrel filled miraculously with penitent’s tears.

Ward II 664; Herbert III *341, 475; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Miraculously loud noise of mourning for hero.

content:
Bones temporarily removed from body by tree climbers to
avoid breaking them.

*Sartori Zs. f. Vksk. VII 113, 270, VIII 29; England: Baughman;
Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 72 No. 610; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3610.
child: Sunken bell sounds at certain times.
Sickness cured by napkin of Veronica.
Extreme anger as cure for sickness.

(Cf. †F955.) Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 358; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Wife cures self of catarrh by calling to husband fondling
maid at bedside.
Measuring sick as means of cure.

Zachariae Zs. f. Vksk. XXI 151; England, Ireland, Wales,
U.S.: Baughman.

Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 55, 90; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.
Extreme fear as cure for sickness.
Princess cured by seeing her lost lover dance.
Healing by sprinkling water and replacing flesh.
Hunchback cured by having hump severely beaten.

India: *Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 233; Africa
(Nyanja): Rattray Some Folk-Lore Stories and Songs in Chinyanja (London, 1907)
149ff. No. 24.
Sight miraculously restored while poet writes hymn (poem).
Blinded prince forces goddess to give him back his sight.
Blindness cured by rubbing sand on eyes.
Blindness cured by striking eyes with shell.

Africa (Nyanja): Rattray Some Folk-Lore Stories and Songs
in Chinyanja (London, 1907) 149ff. No. 24.
Blindness cured by rubbing eyes with flower.
Blindness cured by striking head violently on tree.
Blindness cured by application of chicken dung.

India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Nyanja): Rattray Some
Folk-Lore Stories and Songs in Chinyanja (London, 1907) 149ff. No. 24.

Blindness cured by drop of water from side of crucified
Saviour.
Eyes restored by bathing in lake (spring).

content:
Rage at hearing for first time of Christ‘s passion causes cure.
(Cf. †F950.3.) Irish: Beal XXI 306; English: Wells 155 (Temporale).

Irish myth: *Cross; India: Thompson-Balys; West Indies:
Flowers 438.
child: Thread under dumb man’s tongue cut.
This permits him to speak. Dickson 217.

Dumb princess is brought to speech by tale ending with a
question to be solved.

Chilli plant so hot it causes dumb man to speak: thus
discovered for eating.

Flea (magic) enters princess’ throat and helps hero make
her speak.
Person made to speak by warning of danger.

content: Cure by physician’s imitating sick man‘s actions.

child: Illegitimacy of child discovered by urinalysis.
Diagnosis based on smoke rising from house of sick.

Physician, by examining wound can tell whether it was
inflicted by a man or a woman and describe him or her in detail.

content:
Mountebank undertakes to bring the city’s incurables back
to health.

Effects marvelous cures.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child: Entire household dies on same night.
Roads miraculously appear on day of hero’s birth.
Words heard though only thought and not uttered.
Corn takes root in man’s hair.

Blades of corn grow through hair of saint as reward for
guarding cornkiln.
Man meets his future descendants and is instructed by them.

content: Books in church read without man‘s tongue.

child:
Neophyte shows no reaction when saint’s staff pierces his
foot.

Penzer II 132, VII 24f., 103; Heptameron No. 9; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic:
*Boberg; Greek: Grote I 134; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; West
Indies: Flowers 439.
Heart breaks at third drink from silver canister.
Heart breaks when girl hears lover kiss another.

Hdwb. d. Märchens I 439a n. 267; Irish
myth: *Cross; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 883.
Hearts break when lovers are told beloved is dead.
Death from grief for death of lover or relative.
Woman dies on hearing of her husband’s death.

Woman swoons and is near death at hearing of husband‘s or
lover’s death.

First woman in Ireland to die of grief for the death of her
husband.
Death from hearing of wife‘s death.
Death from hearing of son’s (sons‘) death.

Maiden who has been falsely accused apparently dies of
sorrow.

She revives on being prepared for
burial. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Kills wife and himself. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Woman dies on having secret love exposed.
Priest dies from having been duped into deceptive bargain.
Man dies on learning of wife’s adultery.

Heart breaks when girl learns men are slain in battle on
her account.

Woman dies of broken heart on learning that her former
husband is still alive.

She had remarried
thinking him dead. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 69; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Man dies from grieving over mother‘s death.
Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 77; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Death from excitement at news of Christ’s crucifixion.
Man cannot answer question. Alphabet No. 186.

Guilty persons being confronted with their crimes become
”insensate like trees.“
Heptameron No. 9; India: Thompson-Balys, Penzer VII 103.
Stranger dies from joy on being rewarded by ruler.
Mother dies from joy on greeting long-absent son.
Death from sight of beautiful woman.
Fainting away at sight of goddess.
Man dies when he learns storm is magic.
Suicide from fright of evil prophecy.
Man dies from frog‘s bite, thinking it snakebite.
Girl dies of shame at being seen naked.
Woman dies of shame at seeing naked man (husband).

Hair rises on end in extraordinary fashion from joy, anger, or
love. Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Hindu: Penzer I 120, VII 60, 139 n.
2, 179, VIII 46 n. 1, 94 n. 1; Korean: Zong in-Sob 83; Missouri French:
Carrière.

Irish myth: *Cross; Africa (Efik-Ibibo): Dayrell Folk
Stories from Southern Nigeria (London, 1910) 84; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII
263 No. 68.
Poison of hydra corrodes the skin.
Buttons burst as consequence of violent emotion.
Necklace bursts as consequence of violent emotion.
*Chauvin VII 112 No. 379 bis n. 1; Korean: Zong in-Sob 81.
Madness from sight of magically beautiful man.
Mad warriors fly up into clouds.
Madness from hearing prophetic voice from air.
Madness from regret that knight has forsaken his wife.
Madness (rage) from hearing about brother’s death.
Man keeps to his bed, mourning over drowned son.
King keeps to his bed, mourning over vanished bride.
Woman keeps to her bed on announcement of lover’s death.
Huge boil appears on forehead of youth keeping a secret.
Illness from shame of enemies‘ scorn.

Man sweats blood and absorbs hair into head on exertion of
strength.

Laughing and crying at the same time (sundry reasons
given).

*De Vries FFC LXXIII 213; Gaster
Exempla 130 No. 352; India: *Thompson-Balys, *Bloomfield JAOS XXXVI 54--89,
*Penzer VII 261; Chinese: Chavannes 500 Contes I 160 No. 43, 286 No. 78.
Man turns pale, red, blue, etc. from emotion or strain.
Man perspires in winter while relating fearful vision.
Biting fingers to see if one is dreaming.
Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 88.
One eye recedes, other protrudes when angered.

Man fells wood with sword (dies) when he hears of
Crucifixion.
Strength from anger enables man to break binding chain.
Strength from anger causes man to break stone.
Strength from anger enables man to tear opponent to bits.
Heat of saint’s anger sets cowl afire.

Extraordinary bodily contortion as result of warrior‘s
anger.

Extraordinary physical reactions of angry warriors in
battle.

Fury in battle causes stream of blood to rise from
warrior‘s head.
Fury in battle causes warrior to increase in size.
Fiery columns rise in front of angry warrior.
Face of angry warrior lights up with flame.
Angry warrior becomes red and purple.
Water boils when angry warrior is immersed in it.
Fury enables wounded soldiers to continue fighting.
Die at end of battle. Irish myth: Cross.

Angry warrior‘s breath makes adversary’s armour so hot that
he must surrender.
Bowstring (arrow, oar) breaks at angry warrior‘s grasp.

King about to kill foster-son due to his evil explanation
of dream; both jump into sea and are drowned.
Face and body turn black from anger.
Chief beheads sentinel who does not recognize him.

Man throws cereal and spoon on the floor because he is
supposed to eat together with his brother.
Earl throws jar of water after undesired messenger.
Putrescence flows from head when man presses forehead.
Tears of blood from excessive grief.

Icelandic: Egils saga in
ASB 3 (1894) ch. LXXVIII 14ff., Völsunga saga ch. 31 (29), Boberg.
Refusal to eat from excessive grief.
Refusal to speak because of grief.
Man cries at hearing of friend’s death.

Man senseless from grief at hearing of father‘s death; one
doesn’t feel that he cuts himself with his knife, the other presses dice so
that he bleeds.
Tearing hair and clothes from excessive grief.
Wounding self because of excessive grief.
Bird in great grief tears out feathers.

Shame causes smoke to rise from saint’s head and sweat to
stream from his brow.
Slap turns man‘s face completely around.
Ground opens and swallows heathen idols.
Ground opens and swallows other object.
Extraordinary sword sinks into earth after use.
Ground opens and swallows demoniac wasps.

content:
Schmersel Die Sage von der versunkenen
Stadt; Schütte Danske Studier (1925) 117; Le Braz Légende de la Mort (Paris,
1902); **Smyser Harward Studies and Notes Phil. and Lit. XV (1933) 49ff.;
England: Baughman; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3610.
child: City sinks in sea or lake as punishment.
Ancient homeland sinks beneath the waves.

Earth splits and plain sinks to become bottom of lake when
tabu is broken.

content:
U.S.: Baughman; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (Greenland):
Rink 372, Rasmussen III 185, (Smith Sound): Kroeber JAFL XII 182; West Indies:
Flowers 438.
child: Ground opens and swallows up person.

Irish: *Cross, Beal XXI 327; Icelandic: *Boberg; Greek:
Fox 63 (Althaimenes), 227 (Persephone), Frazer Apollodorus II 241 n. 5; Jewish:
*Neuman; Africa: Werner African 200.

U.S.: Baughman; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; Eskimo
(Kodiak): Golder JAFL XVI 28.
Earth opens at woman‘s bidding to enclose her.

content:
Icelandic: Boberg; Czech: Tille FFC XXXIV
96; Lithuanian: Leskien-Brugmann 385 No. 10, 557 No. 14; Greek: Hahn
Griechische und albanesische Märchen II 273; Egyptian: Maspero Contes populaire
de l’Egypte ancienne (Paris, 1882) 191;
Africa: Meinhof Afrikanische 78, Frobenius Atlantis X 212.
child: Irish myth: Cross; Eskimo (Greenland): Rasmussen III 98.
Church sinks: song heard from underground.

*Fb ”kirke“ IV 258b; Finnish: Aarne FFC XXXIII 47 No. 87;
Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 134 No. 87.
Church and congregation sink to bottom of sea.

Finnish: Aarne FFC XXXIII 46 No. 86**; Estonian: Aarne FFC
XXV 134 No. 86.
Unfinished Tower of Babel sinks into earth.
Fire bends bough to shape of crozier.
Fire spares saint‘s tunic, though wearer is burned.
Extraordinary corpse burns of its own accord.
Blazing stick continues to burn even in water.
